item.title: Fed’s Daly Says US Economy Still Solid, Officials Can Be Patient
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said the strength of the US economy allows policymakers to be patient as they wait for more evidence of how the Trump administration’s policies will affect businesses and households.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly.

item.title: Daly Says Fed Policy Well Positioned, US Growth Solid
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly says monetary policy is moderately restrictive and well positioned to respond to any changes in the economy during a fireside chat at the California Bankers Association’s 2025 Annual Conference and Directors Forum.

item.title: Saks Bond Suffers $1 Billion Loss Before a Single Payment Is Made
item.description: It was supposed to be just what Saks needed to turn things around. By taking over struggling rival Neiman Marcus, the pitch went, the iconic retailer would become a luxury powerhouse — one with enough bargaining and pricing power to cut costs and boost profitability.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Ronalds-Hannon

media:content.media:description: A Saks Fifth Avenue shopper in New York.

item.title: The College Sports Buzz With Georgia Tech’s J Batt
item.description: Alex Rodriguez and Jason Kelly sit with Georgia Tech Athletics Director J Batt during March Madness to discuss the buzz around college athletics, including NIL and the transfer portal. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Listed Subsidiaries Get the Ax in Japan After Investor Pressure
item.description: Japanese conglomerates are scaling back their hundreds of listed subsidiaries, a structure that critics say is often a poor use of capital and raises potential conflicts of interest.
item.dc:creator: Hideyuki Sano, Kanoko Matsuyama

media:content.media:description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp. (NTT) logo outside Otemachi First Square, which houses the company's head office, in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. NTT plans to take over NTT Data Group Corp. in a deal worth ¥2.37 trillion ($16.5 billion), broadening its AI ambitions while heeding regulators’ calls for Japanese conglomerates to streamline unwieldy structures.

item.title: S&P 500 Rally Wavers as Buyer Fatigue Kicks In: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street’s epic rebound from April’s meltdown is showing signs of exhaustion on speculation stocks have run too fast amid risks stemming from a trade war to an economic slowdown and sticky inflation.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.

item.title: Wharton's Siegel: Trade Clarity a Plus, GDP to Take Hit
item.description: Jeremy Siegel, professor emeritus of finance at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, says market uncertainty has cleared up substantially while discussing the global economic impact of tariffs. Speaking on "Bloomberg The Close," Siegel also says he expects the US to take a GDP hit this year. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Why US-Listed Chinese Stocks Risk Expulsion in Trump’s Trade War
item.description: Tariffs aren’t the only battleground to keep an eye on in the trade war between the US and China. Access to Wall Street could be used as a lever in the negotiations, leaving almost 300 Chinese companies listed in the US at risk of being removed from American stock exchanges. That includes e-commerce giants Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. and JD.com Inc.
item.dc:creator: Yiqin Shen

media:content.media:description: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. signage on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange on April 11, 2025.

item.title: S&P 500 Grinds Higher As Chipmakers’ Shares Rise on Gulf Deals
item.description: US stocks posted a slim gain on Wednesday, as chipmakers’ shares advanced after a series of high-profile deals announced during President Donald Trump’s tour of the Persian Gulf while gains in the broader market slowed after a blistering rally.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Stocks End Mixed After Choppy Session | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Alix Steel, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trading Platform EToro Surges 29% After Upsized US IPO
item.description: EToro Group Ltd. shares rose 29% in its first session as a public company, after the trading and investment platform and some of its backers raised nearly $620 million in an upsized IPO.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin, Anthony Hughes

item.title: CFR President Froman on Trade Deals, Tariffs, US Economy
item.description: Council on Foreign Relations President Michael Froman discusses the recent US trade deals with China and the UK, President Donald Trump's tariff strategy and the state of the US economy on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Maryland’s Credit Rating Gets Downgraded as Governor Blames Trump
item.description: Maryland had its credit rating downgraded one level to Aa1 from Aaa by Moody’s Ratings because of its exposure to shifting federal policies, according to a Wednesday report.
item.dc:creator: Arvelisse Bonilla Ramos

media:content.media:description: Wes Moore, governor of Maryland, speaks during the 2025 National Retirement Summit in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. The event brings together industry leaders, policymakers, and executives to prioritize policy supporting personal savings.

item.title: Coinbase CEO on Being Added to S&P, Regulation, M&A
item.description: Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong discusses on being added to the S&P 500, replacing Discover Financial Services in the index. He also discusses the Trump administration's initiative of stablecoin legislation and mergers and acquisitions in an interview with Sonali Basak on "Bloomberg Markets." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US May Need a Bond-Market Blowup to Cut Deficit, Market Veteran Says
item.description: After the November election, there were few people in the bond market more optimistic about how President Donald Trump, and his band of DOGE cost-cutters, would rein in ballooning budget deficits than Stephen Jen.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

item.title: Treasuries Slip Again as Traders Trim Back Bets on Fed Rate Cuts
item.description: Treasury yields climbed on Wednesday — sending the two-year note’s to the highest level since March — as traders further pared wagers on more than one Federal Reserve interest-rate cut by year-end.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Stanton

media:content.media:description: The Treasury Department Building, in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. Photographer: Aaron Schwartz/Bloomberg

item.title: Village Roadshow, Warner Bros. to Delay Fight Over ‘Matrix’ Debt
item.description: The two movie studios behind The Matrix films are putting off fighting over as much as $100 million in unpaid debt related to the movies until after an auction for the film library of bankrupt filmmaker Village Roadshow Entertainment Group.
item.dc:creator: Steven Church

media:content.media:description: Warner Bros. Studios in Burbank, California.

item.title: Millions of Americans at Risk of Summer Power Shortfall, Regulator Says
item.description: Millions of Americans from the upper Midwest to the Gulf Coast are facing the biggest threat of power supply shortfalls in the US this summer.
item.dc:creator: Naureen S Malik

media:content.media:description: Power transmission lines near Austin, Texas, US, on Thursday, June 13, 2024. The Texas grid repeatedly has suffered from tight electricity supplies in the past two years as extreme weather and surging power demand stress aging infrastructure.

item.title: The Future of Supersonic Travel
item.description: Boom Supersonic CEO Blake Scholl discusses the future of high-speed flight as Congress considers ending a ban on supersonic travel over US land. Scholl lays out the company’s timeline as it aims for passenger flights in 2029. He joins Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Possible Cracks in Private Credit
item.description: At the Milken Institute Global Conference, some of the biggest players in private credit talked about a possible 'golden' moment amid the recent market volatility. However, there are some industry watchers who still see issues ahead. Bloomberg's Kat Hildago has more on the story. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stephen Hemsley Returns As UnitedHealth CEO
item.description: UnitedHealth Group Inc. is giving Stephen Hemsley a one-time $60 million equity award on top of a $1 million base salary as he begins his second round as chief executive officer of the beleaguered insurer. Bloomberg's John Tozzi reports on the story. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Eight Sleep Plans China Expansion for Sleep Products
item.description: Eight Sleep CEO Matteo Franceschetti discusses the company’s expansion into new global markets and why the sleep tech startup is considering an IPO. He joins Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Declines After Biggest US Crude Stockpile Gain Since March
item.description: Oil dropped after a government report showed US crude inventories rose the most in two months, overshadowing the lingering relief from the trade truce between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: A gas flare burns from a pipe aboard an offshore oil platform in the Persian Gulf's Salman Oil Field, operated by the National Iranian Offshore Oil Co., near Lavan island, Iran, on Thursday, Jan. 5. 2017. Nov. 5 is the day when sweeping U.S. sanctions on Iran’s energy and banking sectors go back into effect after Trump’s decision in May to walk away from the six-nation deal with Iran that suspended them. Photographer: Ali Mohammadi/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Mideast Trip Sparks AI Deals | Bloomberg Markets 05/14/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests; Morgan Stanley Investment Management Senior Portfolio Manager Andrew Slimmon, Coinbase CEO and CO-Founder Brian Armstrong, Bloomberg's Kat Hidalgo, John Tozzi, and Nathan Dean. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Neuberger, Franklin Sign Investment Deals With Saudi Wealth Fund
item.description: Franklin Resources Inc. and Neuberger Berman reached multibillion-dollar investment deals with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, the latest signs that the country is attracting US money managers to invest in the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Silla Brush

media:content.media:description: Attendees visit the Public Investment Fund booth at the Future Investment Initiative conference.

item.title: The Importance of AI Memory
item.description: The US needs to stay at the forefront of algorithmic advancements, says Konstantine Buhler, partner at Sequoia Capital. He discusses the importance of developments in AI memory with Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Morgan Stanley Hires Goldman’s Metals and Mining Head
item.description: Morgan Stanley has hired the global head of metals and mining at rival Goldman Sachs Group Inc. to boost its team of industrials bankers, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: David Carnevali

media:content.media:description: The Morgan Stanley headquarters in New York, US, on Wednesday, Sept. 27, 2023. Morgan Stanley is scheduled to release earnings figures on October 18.

item.title: The Rise of the Solo General Partner
item.description: Josh Browder, founder and CEO of AI legal services startup DoNotPay, explains why he is also running his own venture capital firm as a solo general partner. He talks about the benefits solo GPs can bring young founders with Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Lenore Sports Buys Stake in Portuguese Football Club Benfica
item.description: Lenore Sports Partners, an investment group that includes the co-founder of private equity firm Crescent Capital, has acquired a minority stake in Benfica SAD, the company that manages one of the most valuable Portuguese football clubs.
item.dc:creator: David Hellier, Henrique Almeida

media:content.media:description: SL Benfica players ahead of a match against Sporting Clube de Portugal at Estadio da Luz in Lisbon, Portugal, on May 10, 2025.

item.title: Investing in the AI Buildout
item.description: Nancy Tengler, Laffer Tengler Investments CIO and CEO, says the buildout of artificial intelligence is still in its early days and sees a lot of potential in the software space. Tengler speaks with Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)
